sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using Cholesky decomposition
message_2:
To solve the given system of linear equations using Cholesky decomposition, we first need to write the system in matrix form Ax = b, where A is the matrix of coefficients, x is the column vector of variables, and b is the column vector of constants.

A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
2 & 3 & 3 \\
2 & 5 & 6
\end{bmatrix}

x = \begin{bmatrix}
x \\
y \\
z
\end{bmatrix}

b = \begin{bmatrix}
6 \\
14 \\
23
\end{bmatrix}

Now, we will find the Cholesky decomposition of A, which is a lower triangular matrix L such that A = LL^T.

L = \begin{bmatrix}
l_{11} & 0 & 0 \\
l_{21} & l_{22} & 0 \\
l_{31} & l_{32} & l_{33}
\end{bmatrix}

We can find the elements of L using the following equations:

l_{11} = \sqrt{a_{11}} = \sqrt{1} = 1

l_{21} = a_{21}/l_{11} = 2/1 = 2

l_{31} = a_{31}/l_{11} = 2/1 = 2

l_{22} = \sqrt{a_{22} - l_{21}^2} = \sqrt{3 - 2^2} = \sqrt{1} = 1

l_{32} = (a_{32} - l_{31}l_{21})/l_{22} = (5 - 2*2)/1 = 1

l_{33} = \sqrt{a_{33} - l_{31}^2 - l_{32}^2} = \sqrt{6 - 2^2 - 1^2} = \sqrt{1} = 1

So, the Cholesky decomposition of A is:

L = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
2 & 1 & 0 \\
2 & 1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}

Now, we will solve the system Ly = b for y:

\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
2 & 1 & 0 \\
2 & 1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
y_1 \\
y_2 \\
y_3
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}
6 \\
14 \\
23
\end{bmatrix}

Solving this system, we get:

y_1 = 6

y_2 = 14 - 2*y_1 = 14 - 2*6 = 2

y_3 = 23 - 2*y_1 - y_2 = 23 - 2*6 - 2 = 9

Now, we will solve the system L^Tx = y for x:

\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 & 2 \\
0 & 1 & 1 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
x \\
y \\
z
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}
6 \\
2 \\
9
\end{bmatrix}

Solving this system, we get:

z = 9

y = 2 - z = 2 - 9 = -7

x = 6 - 2*y - 2*z = 6 - 2*(-7) - 2*9 = 1

So, the solution to the given system of linear equations is:

x = 1, y = -7, z = 9
